awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Operationalization of the Structural Extreme Events Reconnaissance (StEER) Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Over 39 percent of the US population live in coastal shoreline counties exposed on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts to meteorological hazards like hurricanes and on the Pacific Coast to geophysical hazards like earthquakes and tsunamis. Meanwhile, much of the remaining population at the interior of the country is subject annually to the damaging effects of thunderstorm downbursts and tornadoes, in addition to the looming threats of potentially catastrophic earthquakes.  Concentrating property and human life in some of the country's most hazard-prone areas inevitably results in catastrophic losses, as powerfully illustrated by the 2017 Hurricane season's sequence of Harvey, Irma, and Maria, which caused the highest insured losses ever.  Each disaster provides an important opportunity to evaluate the performance and vulnerabilities of buildings and other constructed civil infrastructure that led to dramatic losses of life and property. Research (knowledge) advances to reduce risks to civil infrastructure from natural hazard events are strongly guided and informed by field evidence documenting the performance of the built environment after the event. As natural disasters occur with little warning, reconnaissance teams must immediately mobilize over large geographical areas to gather large quantities of perishable research data on civil infrastructure performance that must be effectively captured through a finite number of field observations. While the National Science Foundation uses the Grants for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) funding mechanism to support structural engineering researchers to collect post-event perishable data, the response of the structural engineering community to such extreme events has been ad hoc, leading to slowed in-field response times, uncoordinated data collection, and missed opportunities to maximize learning from disasters. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) responds to this challenge by establishing the Structural Extreme Event Reconnaissance (StEER) network to coordinate the structural engineering research community's rapid response to natural disasters and build its capacity for more effective, systematic, and consistent post-disaster RAPID reconnaissance and data collection. The goal is to use the event data collected for subsequent research investigations to reduce risks to constructed civil infrastructure and thus promote national welfare and prosperity by saving lives and reducing property losses in future disasters. 

This EAGER will guide the community-led design and launch of the StEER network and establish its mission to (1) promote community-driven standards, best practices, and training for coordinated RAPID field work, (2) represent the vision of the structural reconnaissance community outwardly to other aligned organizations, and (3) coordinate official event responses in collaboration with other stakeholders. StEER will be founded upon regional nodes that provide convening points to give voice to the needs of the windstorm and earthquake engineering communities, while establishing common ground to foster interaction between them. These nodes more importantly will enable swift and cost-effective response to disasters. Creating a single point of coordination for the structural engineering research community will also enable better connectivity with the wider established extreme events (EE) consortium in geotechnical engineering and social sciences to foster greater potentials for truly interdisciplinary reconnaissance. StEER will be operationalized through the following objectives: (1) establish its governance structure, policies and data standards to enable more effective, coordinated field reconnaissance by leveraging its geographically distributed network; (2) implement standard workflows for a wide array of assessment technologies to swiftly and reliably capture, curate and disseminate large volumes of perishable research data; (3) increase the community's capacity for high-quality damage assessments through standardization, rigorous quality assurance, and web-based training programs; (4) foster greater collaboration across hazard and disciplinary boundaries through coordination and blended reconnaissance efforts within the wider EE consortium; and (5) promote broad dissemination of high-quality reconnaissance findings to diverse audiences to benefit researchers, practitioners, students, and the public-at-large.  StEER will also coordinate its reconnaissance with the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) RAPID facility and its data archiving with the NHERI cyberinfrastructure Reconnaissance Portal (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Over 39% of the U.S. population lives in coastal shoreline counties exposed on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts to meteorological hazards like hurricanes and on the Pacific Coast to geophysical hazards like earthquakes and tsunamis. Meanwhile, much of the remaining population in the interior of the country is subject annually to the damaging effects of thunderstorm downbursts and tornadoes, in addition to the looming threats of potentially catastrophic earthquakes. Concentrating property and human life in some of the country's most hazard-prone areas inevitably results in catastrophic losses, powerfully demonstrated by 2020's record number of events (22) each causing at least one billion dollars in damage. Each of these disasters reveals how underlying vulnerabilities in buildings and other civil infrastructure drives dramatic losses of life and property. However, if effectively seized, these disasters create a valuable opportunity to deepen our understanding of how to design more resilient and sustainable communities in the future.

In response, this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) established the Structural Extreme Event Reconnaissance (StEER) network to build the capacity of the structural engineering community to conduct these vital post-disaster investigations. Specifically, this project established a governance structure, policies and protocols to coordinate a geographically-distributed network of over 270 volunteer structural engineers in the response to 48 hazard events such as earthquakes, tornadoes, hurricanes and tsunamis. These members have been equipped with an array of assessment technologies including two dozen mobile apps that have been used to swiftly capture over 20,000 standardized structural assessments. By engaging commercial, governmental and non-governmental organizations also responding to these events, StEER has effectively expanded the reach of its efforts, attracting nearly 300 additional users to its mobile applications.The data collected by its platforms has revealed the root causes of damage to the built environment and presented recommendations to reverse these costly trends, broadly disseminated to researchers, practitioners, policy makers and the public-at-large through 48 briefings, reports and other products.

Evaluating the performance of the built environment after major disasters ensures our country can identify research priorities and associated changes to policy and practice necessary to advance more resilient, economical and sustainable civil infrastructure. By (1) broadening the participation of a diverse engineering workforce in StEER's efforts, (2) building their capacity to meaningfully engage in post-disaster data gathering, (3) ensuring immediate and open access to the valuable data they collect, and (4) efficiently synthesizing key insights from this data, this project has ensured more effective learning from these disasters with the aim of reducing the mounting losses of life and property.  Moreover, by swiftly sharing its data and learnings with municipal, county, state, federal and international authorities, StEER has positively contributed to the recovery and rebuilding process after major disasters like Hurricanes Michael (2018), Dorian (2019), Laura (2020) and Ida (2021), the Nashville Tornadoes (2020), and devastating earthquakes in Puerto Rico (2019/2020) and Haiti (2021). 


Last Modified: 12/05/2021
Modified by: Tracy L Kijewski-Correa

Images (1 of )
  • StEER Field Assessment Structural Team members Justin Marshall, Daniel Smith and Andrew Lyda forensically evaluate an overturned residence on Great Abaco Island in the Bahamas following Hurricane Dorian.

    The Power of Nature
  • StEER Member Justin Marshall measures high water mark at South Cameron High School in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura in Louisiana.
    David Roueche
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Marking a Design-Level Hurricane
  • Haitian community members use special Creole-language Fulcrum App to document damage across three departments following 14 August 2021 Nippes earthquake when security conditions prohibited travel to Haiti.
    Veronique Joseph
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    A Truly Local Response
  • StEER Member Sabarethinam Kameshwar and StEER Associate Director for Data Standards David Roueche attach a panoramic imaging system to their vehicle to rapidly collect surface imagery after Hurricane Ida struck during another COVID-19-surge in Louisiana.
    Brandon Rittelmeyer
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    A Swift Response in a Pandemic
  • StEER Associate Director for Coastal Hazards, Ian Robertson, joins an international response to Indonesia�s Palu Earthquake and Tsunami organized by Tomoya Shibayama of Waseda University (Japan) and included local Indonesian, Japanese, American, Canadian and German investigators.
    Ian Robertson
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Learning from Disaster Through International Collaboration
  • Through a cooperative mission between StEER and Stanford�s Blume Center, Team Lead Professor Eduardo Miranda and his student photograph exposed reinforcement in the pancake collapse of the Agripina Seda School in Gu�nica, Puerto Rico in the midst of ongoing aftershocks in the Dec 19/Jan 20 sequence.
    Eduardo Miranda
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Responding Amid the Aftershocks
  • StEER Associate Director for Coastal Hazards, Ian Robertson, joins an international response to Indonesia�s Palu Earthquake and Tsunami organized by Tomoya Shibayama of Waseda University (Japan) and included local Indonesian, Japanese, American, Canadian and German investigators.
    Ian Robertson
    Creative Commons
    Tracy L Kijewski-Correa
    Learning from Disaster Through International Collaboration
